node.title: Ukraine and Russian-backed rebels accuse each other of shelling
node.description: War has simmered in eastern Ukraine for almost 8 years, but with the U.S. accusing Russia of adding, not removing forces in the region, the crisis "can ignite at any moment."

node.title: Fatal shark attack closes Sydney beaches as great white is sought
node.description: The shark is believed to be 10 feet long. It was the first fatal shark attack in Australia's largest city since 1963.

node.title: Keeping pool only 'lipstick' for suburb - deputy mayor
node.description: Napier councillors are divided on whether the city's ageing and outdated pool should be closed.

node.title: Covid-19 update: 1573 new community cases
node.description: The Ministry of Health is reporting 1573 new community cases of Covid-19 in New Zealand today.

node.title: NZ nurses overworked and exhausted - report
node.description: A major independent report has found nurses are overworked and exhausted because of consistent understaffing and that patients are not always getting full care.

node.title: No dialogue with protesters until blockade clears
node.description: All parties in Parliament have united under a clear declaration to the protesters outside - there will be no dialogue while illegal activity persists.

node.title: Canada beats U.S. 3-2 to win women's hockey gold at Beijing Games
node.description: The Canadians took back the gold the U.S. had grabbed from them at the 2018 Pyeongchang Games.

node.title: Visa application software needs clear oversight  - advocates
node.description: Immigration and human rights lawyers say there needs to be clear oversight of the software Immigration New Zealand is using to help process visa applications.

node.title: Stock market operator NZX reports 15% drop in full year profit
node.description: Chief executive Mark Peterson said the drop in profit was a result of a lower return on investments and increased costs, including ongoing investment in technology.

node.title: Canada beats U.S. 3-2 to win women's ice hockey gold at Beijing Games
node.description: The Canadians took back the gold the U.S. had grabbed from them at the 2018 Pyeongchang Games.

node.title: Negotiations for NZ taking refugees from Australia ongoing
node.description: Australian's Home Affairs essentially says there is an "in principle deal" - but the NZ government is staying mum about any significant progress on acceptance of a long standing offer to take 150…

node.title: 'The law has failed': Cranmer Square residents say protesters camping illegally
node.description: Cranmer Square residents say Christchurch City Council is quick to send notices for branches hanging outside their property, but is sitting quiet while protesters are on their doorstep.

node.title: Shark attack kills swimmer in Sydney bay
node.description: A shark attack on Wednesday afternoon killed a swimmer off a Sydney beach, causing "catastrophic injuries", police and ambulance services say.

node.title: Buller state of emergency extended, rural communities hardest by floods
node.description: The state of emergency in the Buller district has been extended as the council assesses flood damage estimated to have cost millions of dollars.

node.title: Covid-19: Cases identified at 320 schools and ECEs
node.description: New figures show 30 percent of Auckland schools are managing cases, with infections rising particularly rapidly at primary schools.

node.title: Black Caps face in-form South Africa
node.description: South Africa's unbeaten Test series record against the Black Caps has been a focus for the visitors in their build-up to the first Test.

node.title: Government launches Te Mahere Whai Mahi Māori strategy
node.description: Minister of Social Development Carmel Sepuloni says the strategy will ensure Māori have the skills and knowledge to both lead and excel and get them into jobs.

node.title: FAA Administrator Steve Dickson resigns, will leave at the end of March
node.description: "It has been the privilege of a lifetime to serve alongside you," Dickson wrote in an email to FAA employees.

node.title: Pacquiao to fight drugs 'the right way' if elected president
node.description: Philippines boxing icon and presidential candidate Manny Pacquiao says he will welcome an international probe into President Rodrigo Duterte's war on drugs if elected, and promised to fight narcotics…

node.title: Slovakia wins shootout against USA
node.description: No medals in Ice hockey for U.S. or Canada after shock quarter-final wins for Slovakia and Sweden

node.title: Skellerup delivers $23.2m half-year profit
node.description: Strong demand from the industrial sectors has helped the rubber goods manufacturer Skellerup deliver a record half-year profit.

node.title: Parliament protest: Vehicle towing yet to start, police 'focus on engagement'
node.description: Police in Wellington are not yet towing protester vehicles blocking streets around Parliament, and say they are exercising "careful judgement" about when to start.

node.title: Judge says Palin jurors knew he planned to toss claim before they reached a verdict
node.description: The judge said the jurors told a law clerk it didn't affect the outcome.

node.title: Education Department to forgive $415 million in student debt
node.description: The latest round of loan forgiveness brings the total amount approved by the department to approximately $2 billion for more than 107,000 borrowers.

node.title: 'This is not okay': Fed up nurse defaces anti-vax billboard
node.description: A Whangārei nurse is so annoyed by anti-vaccination billboards in Northland, she wore a disguise and spraypainted over misinformation. Audio

node.title: MIQ rules begin to loosen as border opens and Omicron spreads
node.description: More people are expected to be able to leave MIQ early under a new risk assessment, and some travellers may be able to go into self-isolation before borders open.

node.title: Covid-19: NZ Post boosts staffing in preparation for sustained outbreak
node.description: The postal service says 800 extra staff will ensure critical deliveries can continue as the Omicron outbreak grows.

node.title: European Union ambassador says Russia-Ukraine crisis has unified EU and NATO
node.description: Lambrinidis said he is still hopeful that the tensions can be dealt with via diplomacy.

node.title: Survivor tells Abuse in Care inquiry alcohol 'eased the pain'
node.description: A survivor of abuse at the hands of the Catholic Order of St John of God has told the Royal Commission of Inquiry about his treatment at Marylands School - saying he was "interfered with" as soon as…

node.title: 'It's at tipping point': Residents fear influx of helicopters
node.description: Aotea Great Barrier islanders fear they will go the same way as Waiheke Island with lots of helicopters buzzing their skies.
